results.title: Who Is Jennifer Lawrence Now?
results.abstract: The Oscar-winning “Hunger Games” actress is free from her franchise commitments. But after a brief hiatus from acting, what will she do next?

multimedia.caption: “I obviously cannot relate to risking my life for my country,” Jennifer Lawrence said, “but I can understand, reading ‘Causeway,’ why I’m getting so emotional about somebody who doesn’t feel like they belong anywhere unless they’re on a schedule.”
multimedia.copyright: Robbie Lawrence for The New York Times

multimedia.caption: “I obviously cannot relate to risking my life for my country,” Jennifer Lawrence said, “but I can understand, reading ‘Causeway,’ why I’m getting so emotional about somebody who doesn’t feel like they belong anywhere unless they’re on a schedule.”

results.title: Winter Movies 2022: Here’s What’s Coming Soon to Streaming and Theaters
results.abstract: The season’s gifts include long-awaited sequels to “Black Panther” and “Knives Out” and intriguing originals like “Women Talking” and “The Fabelmans.”

results.title: ‘Bardo, False Chronicle of a Handful of Truths’ Review: It’s a Stressful Afterlife
results.abstract: In Alejandro G. Iñárritu’s sprawling, intensely personal new film, a prominent journalist grapples with work, family, metaphysics and the paradoxes of Mexican history.
des_facet: Bardo, False Chronicle of a Handful of Truths (Movie)

multimedia.caption: Daniel Giménez Cacho in “Bardo.” He plays Silverio, a character who bears a resemblance to the film’s director, Alejandro G. Iñárritu.

results.title: ‘Good Night Oppy’ Review: Life (Kind of) on Mars
results.abstract: NASA’s Opportunity and Spirit rovers didn’t shoot cinematic-quality footage of Mars, but this documentary offers the next-best thing.

multimedia.caption: The documentary “Good Night Oppy” looks at rovers NASA created to survey and photograph Mars.
The documentary “Good Night Oppy” looks at rovers NASA created to survey and photograph Mars.
The documentary “Good Night Oppy” looks at rovers NASA created to survey and photograph Mars.

results.title: ‘Selena Gomez: My Mind and Me’ Review: An Honest Portrait of Stardom
results.abstract: Sincere and soul-baring, the documentary, directed by Alek Keshishian, captures Gomez’s challenges with mental illness, lupus and fame.
des_facet: Selena Gomez: My Mind and Me (Movie)

multimedia.caption: In “Selena Gomez: My Mind and Me,” the singer is in the trustworthy hands of the veteran director Alek Keshishian.
In “Selena Gomez: My Mind and Me,” the singer is in the trustworthy hands of the veteran director Alek Keshishian.

results.title: How ‘Babylon’ Roars Through the 1920s

results.title: James Cameron and the Cast of ‘Avatar: The Way of Water’ Hold Their Breath
results.abstract: The original was the biggest hit ever, but the sequel still took a long time to come together. How will it resonate in a different era of moviegoing?

multimedia.caption: The “Avatar” sequel arrives 13 years after the original, and now Sam Worthington’s Jake Sully, at right, is the father of a brood.

results.title: ‘Salvatore: Shoemaker of Dreams’ Review: For the Heel of It

results.title: John David Washington Gets an Education in ‘The Piano Lesson’

results.title: In ‘Dangerous Liaisons,’ Alice Englert and Nicholas Denton Play the Game
results.abstract: In a decadent new Starz drama, the two actors play young versions of literature’s most poisoned and poisonous power couple.

results.title: Julie Powell, Food Writer Known for ‘Julie & Julia,’ Dies at 49
results.abstract: She attempted to cook every recipe in a classic Julia Child cookbook and documented the effort in a popular blog that became a best-selling book and a hit movie.

results.title: Barry Keoghan Doesn’t Mean to Be a Scene-Stealer
results.abstract: The Irish character actor has earned praise as a supporting player in movies like “The Banshees of Inisherin,” but he’s ready to be a star.

multimedia.caption: “The scene-stealing thing — it’s nice, but I don’t want to be known as that,” Barry Keoghan said. “I want people to see me and think, ‘That boy can hold a movie.’”
“The scene-stealing thing — it’s nice, but I don’t want to be known as that,” Barry Keoghan said. “I want people to see me and think, ‘That boy can hold a movie.’”

results.title: Behind 3 Champions’ Smithsonian Portraits
results.abstract: Serena and Venus Williams and Ava DuVernay, and the artists who portrayed them, talk about their choices, which will be on view at the National Portrait Gallery.

multimedia.caption: Robert Pruitt’s portrait of Venus Williams. “My hope,” he said, “is that the duality of the portrait gives us this sense of a person looking back at themselves, considering where they came from and where they’re going.”
multimedia.copyright: Robert Pruitt; via National Portrait Gallery, Smithsonian Institution

results.title: Ben Platt on the Unfortunate Timeliness of His ‘Parade’ Revival
results.abstract: The 29-year-old actor, best known for his Tony-winning turn in “Dear Evan Hansen,” this week returns to the stage at New York City Center.

multimedia.caption: “Parade,” Ben Platt said, “is all about not only antisemitism, but the failure of the country to protect lots of marginalized groups, and we’re all feeling that really intensely right now.”
multimedia.copyright: Vincent Tullo for The New York Times

results.title: Overlooked No More: Dorothy Spencer, Film Editor Sought Out by Big Directors
results.abstract: She worked with Alfred Hitchcock, Elia Kazan, Frank Capra and John Ford, and she was known for her deft touch, particularly with action movies.

multimedia.caption: The film editor Dorothy Spencer in 1938. “You get so involved in what you’re doing, in the challenge of creating — because I think cutting is very creative,” she once said.
The film editor Dorothy Spencer in 1938. “You get so involved in what you’re doing, in the challenge of creating — because I think cutting is very creative,” she once said.
The film editor Dorothy Spencer in 1938. “You get so involved in what you’re doing, in the challenge of creating — because I think cutting is very creative,” she once said.

results.title: Sacheen Littlefeather and the Question of Native Identity
results.abstract: The actress, who died Oct. 2, became famous for a protest at the 1973 Oscars. Now a researcher and Littlefeather’s own sisters dispute her claims that she was Native American. Her defenders say Indian identity is a complex matter.
results.byline: By Eduardo Medina and Michael Levenson
org_facet: Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences

multimedia.caption: Sacheen Littlefeather at an event in September in her honor at the Academy Museum in Los Angeles. She was joined by Bird Runningwater, the co-chairman of the Academy’s Indigenous Alliance.
Sacheen Littlefeather at an event in September in her honor at the Academy Museum in Los Angeles. She was joined by Bird Runningwater, the co-chairman of the Academy’s Indigenous Alliance.
